across.text: Reg maybe backing Paul the physicist
across.explanation: DIRAC(i.e. “Paul the physicist”). Solution is CAR ID (i.e. “reg maybe”, a playful reference to a car registration) reversed (indicated by “backing”). Made. To. Fit.

across.text: Yankee after arrest to be sick as a parrot?
across.explanation: COPYCAT(i.e. to “parrot”). Solution is Y (“Yankee” in the phonetic alphabet) placed “after” COP (i.e. to “arrest”) and followed by CAT (i.e. “to be sick” – can’t place the usage, but Chambers backs it up), like so: COP-(Y)-CAT.

across.text: Symbol from memory needed on most of elite kit
across.explanation: PICTOGRAM(i.e. “symbol”). Solution is RAM (i.e. computer “memory”, specifically Random Access Memory) placed “on” or after PICK (i.e. “elite”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “most of…”) and TOG (i.e. “kit”, both words for clothing), like so: (PIC-TOG)-RAM.

across.text: Leaving it to fuzz? One presumably not
across.explanation: VIGILANTE. Clue plays on “fuzz” being a slang word for the police, and how vigilantes act outside of the law. Not picking much else up from this one, to be honest. I could be missing something clever.

across.text: A welcome game of cricket forces our Elizabeth to stop arguing?
across.explanation: AGREE TO DIFFER(i.e. “stop arguing”). Solution is A followed by GREET (i.e. “welcome”), then ODI (i.e. “game of cricket”, specifically a One Day International), then F and F (recognised abbreviations of “force”), then ER (i.e. “our Elizabeth”, i.e. the Queen, or Elizabeth Regina).

across.text: A little foreign cash needs dispatched to auditor, as I see it
across.explanation: CENTIMO(i.e. “a little foreign cash”). Solution is a homophone (indicated by “to auditor”) of SENT (i.e. “dispatched”) followed by IMO (i.e. “as I see it”, specifically an abbreviation of In My Opinion), like so: CENT-IMO.

across.text: Compounds skill fabulously with a touch of aplomb
across.explanation: ALKILIS(i.e. “compounds”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “fabulously”) of SKILL, A and A (i.e. “a touch of aplomb”, i.e. the first letter of “aplomb”).

across.text: Haze from rear crossing unobstructed, largely
across.explanation: SEA FRET(i.e. “haze”). Solution is SEAT (i.e. “rear”) wrapped around or “crossing” FREE (i.e. “unobstructed”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “largely”), like so: SEA(FRE)T.

across.text: Explain I must have quiet at rave
across.explanation: TALK THROUGH ONE’S HAT(i.e. “rave” or talk insensibly). Solution is TALK THROUGH (i.e. “explain”) followed by ONE (i.e. “I”, its Roman numeral equivalent), then SH (i.e. “quiet”) and AT.

across.text: After first of January, pub serves spirits
across.explanation: JINN(i.e. “spirits”). Solution is J (i.e. “first [letter] of January”) followed by INN (i.e. “pub”).

across.text: A large Lowry? Remarkable Irish drawing
across.explanation: ALL SQUARE(i.e. “drawing”). Solution is A followed by L (a recognised abbreviation of “large”) followed by LS (initials of artist “Lowry”), then QUARE (i.e. “remarkable Irish”, i.e. a dialectical variation of QUEER).

across.text: Twig gate’s not closing right
across.explanation: WICKER(i.e. “twig”). Solution is WICKET (i.e. “gate”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “not closing”) and the remainder followed by R (a recognised abbreviation of “right”), like so: WICKE-R.

across.text: Space probe that’s reached across third of universe
across.explanation: GIOTTO(i.e. “space probe” used to observe Halley’s comet up close in the mid-1980s). Solution is GOT TO (i.e. “reached”) wrapped around or placed “across” I (i.e. “third [letter] of universe”), like so: G(I)OT-TO. Made. To. Fit.

across.text: Aim to put on air transport
across.explanation: EXPRESS TRAIN(i.e. “transport”). Solution is TRAIN (i.e. to “aim”) placed “on” or after EXPRESS (i.e. to “air”, say, an opinion).

across.text: To perform, men getting in camera
across.explanation: CLOSED-DOOR(i.e. “in camera”, or in secret). Solution is CLOSED (as in a door being closed “to”) followed by DO (i.e. “perform”) and OR (i.e. “men”, specifically the Other Ranks of the British Army).

across.text: Updates record, having finally included it in a bizarre ritual
across.explanation: AUDIT TRAIL(i.e. “updates record”). Solution is D (i.e. “finally included”, i.e. the last letter of “included”) and IT both placed “in” A and an anagram (indicated by “bizarre”) of RITUAL, like so: A-U(D-IT)TRAIL.

across.text: Place for one of the cabal, later evacuated frantically
across.explanation: BACHELOR FLAT(i.e. “place for one”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “frantically”) of OF THE CABAL and LR (i.e. “later evacuated”, i.e. the word “later” with all its middle letters removed).

across.text: Help to push horse back: that’s painful, indeed!
across.explanation: AND HOW(i.e. “indeed!”). Solution is HAND (i.e. “help”) with the H (i.e. “horse”, both slang words for heroin) “pushed…back” and followed by OW (i.e. “that’s painful”), like so: (H)AND-OW => AND(H)-OW.

across.text: Some inside sang – or applauded yarn
across.explanation: ANGORA(i.e. “yarn”). “Some inside” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: S(ANG OR A)PPLAUDED.

across.text: Unwrapped afternoon treat carried by mother, the perfect combination!
across.explanation: DREAM TEAM(i.e. “the perfect combination”). Solution is CREAM TEA (i.e. “afternoon treat”) with the first and last letters removed (indicated by “unwrapped”) and the remainder placed in or “carried by” DAM (i.e. “mother”, a cattle-related usage we’ve seen occasionally in Jumbos), like so: D(REAM-TE)AM.

across.text: You might catch one at sea, or catch one at the piano
across.explanation: TUNA(i.e. “you might catch one at sea”). The solution is a homophone (indicated by “catch” or to hear) of TUNER (i.e. “one at the piano”).

across.text: Warning people passed on should be believed?
across.explanation: DEAD MEN TELL NO TALES(i.e. a “warning”). Clue plays on DEAD MEN being “people passed on” and how TALES are often referred to as lies. If one TELLS NO TALES then they “should be believed”. You get the idea.

across.text: One’s more ineffectual executioner?
across.explanation: IMPALER(i.e. “executioner”). When written as I’M PALER the solution also satisfies “one’s more ineffectual”.

across.text: Education publication’s, I hesitate to say, a little square
across.explanation: TESSERA(i.e. a “little square” used in a mosaic). Solution is TES’S (i.e. “education publication’s”, specifically theTimes Educational Supplement) followed by ER (i.e. “I hesitate to say”) and A.

across.text: First taxi maybe about to drive brother from Spain?
across.explanation: CARAMBA(i.e. “brother from Spain”, playing on “brother” being an exclamation). Solution is CAB A (i.e. “first taxi maybe”) wrapped “about” RAM (i.e. “to drive” into something), like so: CA(RAM)B-A.

across.text: Miscreant errs with abandon in Mormon city
across.explanation: SAN BERNARDINO(i.e. “Mormon city”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “miscreant”) of ERRS and ABANDON IN.

across.text: Private network, small one, not English, is being moved
across.explanation: IN TRANSIT(i.e. “being moved”). Solution is INTRANET (i.e. “private network”) with the E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”) swapped for (indicated by “not”) S (a recognised abbreviation of “small”) and I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”), like so: INTRAN(E)T => INTRAN(S-I)T.

across.text: PC meeting army officers? It’s a small world!
across.explanation: MICROCOSM(i.e. “it’s a small world”). Solution is MICRO (i.e. computer or “PC”) followed by CO and SM (both “army officers”, a Commanding Officer and a Sergeant Major respectively).

across.text: Cheat Harry getting into row
across.explanation: FINAGLE(i.e. “cheat”). Solution is NAG (i.e. to “harry” – ignore the misleading capitalisation) placed “into” FILE (i.e. a line or “row”), like so: FI(NAG)LE.

across.text: Wash thoroughly and comb
across.explanation: SCOUR. Solution satisfies “wash thoroughly” and to “comb” or search.

down.text: Within Homer’s house perhaps there’s name for later poet’s
down.explanation: DOVE COTTAGE(i.e. a “house” in which the “poet” William Wordsworth lived). Solution is DOVECOTE (i.e. “homer’s house” – ignore the misleading capitalisation, this is a reference to homing birds) wrapped around or having “within” TAG (i.e. “name”), like so: DOVECOT(TAG)E.

down.text: Ungrateful daughter of stage manager’s showing up
down.explanation: REGAN(i.e. “ungrateful daughter of stage”, specifically in William Shakespeare’sKing Lear). “Showing” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, while “up” indicates the solution has been reversed – this being a down clue, like so: MA(NAGER).

down.text: All fashionable ladies’ hats eclipsed by suit, without a doubt
down.explanation: CALL INTO QUESTION(i.e. “doubt”). Solution is ALL, IN (i.e. “fashionable”) and TOQUES (i.e. “ladies’ hats”) all placed in or “eclipsed by” ACTION (i.e. legal “suit”) once the A has been removed (indicated by “without a”), like so: C(ALL-IN-TOQUES)TION.

down.text: Being open, willing and positive, game turned around
down.explanation: CANDOUR(i.e. “being open”). Solution is CAN DO (i.e. “willing and positive”) followed by RU (i.e. “game”, specifically Rugby Union) reversed (indicated by “turned around”), like so: (CAN-DO)-UR.

down.text: Rash more manageable on reflection, with no spots around
down.explanation: PREMATURE(i.e. “rash”). Solution is TAMER (i.e. “more manageable”) reversed (indicated by “on reflection”) and placed in or having “around” PURE (i.e. “no spots”), like so: P(REMAT)URE.

down.text: Be suddenly assertive in finally mastering that dessert recipe?
down.explanation: CRACK THE WHIP. Solution satisfies “be suddenly assertive” and, playfully, “finally mastering that dessert recipe”. I rather liked this one.

down.text: Sweater something the unfortunate canoeist may turn down
down.explanation: TURTLENECK(i.e. “sweater”). Solution is TURTLE (i.e. “something the unfortunate canoeist may turn”) followed by NECK (i.e. to “down” a drink).

down.text: Supports old ploughman in work
down.explanation: PIERS. Solution satisfies “supports” and “old ploughman in work”, a reference to a fourteenth century poem calledPiers The Ploughmanascribed to William Langland. A new one on me. Chalk one to my Bradford’s.

down.text: Part of goal put out by legal people generally
down.explanation: CROSSBAR(i.e. “part of goal”). Solution is CROSS (i.e. angered or “put out”) followed by BAR (i.e. “legal people generally”).

down.text: Round holiday time carrying one’s “bag for life”?
down.explanation: OVISAC(i.e. “bag for life”, or egg capsule). Solution is O (i.e. “round”) followed by VAC (i.e. “holiday time”, short for vacation) once wrapped around or “carrying” I’S (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one’s”), like so: O-V(I’S)AC.

down.text: One who’d make improvements dealing with health first
down.explanation: REFORMIST(i.e. “one who’d make improvements”). Solution is RE (i.e. “dealing with” – think email replies) followed by FORM (i.e. “health”) and IST (i.e. “first”, with I being a Roman numeral one).

down.text: Battle site’s ruins by chance not recalled
down.explanation: MARSTON MOOR(i.e. “battle site”). Solution is MARS (i.e. “ruins”) followed by ROOM (i.e. “chance” – over to Chambers: “opportunity, scope or occasion”) and NOT once these latter two have been reversed (indicated by “recalled”), like so: MARS-(TON-MOOR).

down.text: Pal idly twisting leaf
down.explanation: LILY PAD(i.e. “leaf”). “Twisting” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of PAL IDLY.

down.text: Cautious movement – fraction of half-inch as it were?
down.explanation: STEALTH(i.e. “cautious movement”). The remainder of the clue plays on “half-inch” being cockney rhyming slang for pinch, or to STEAL, and TH being a suffix denoting a “fraction” of something.

down.text: Dramatise larkish, unconventional trilogy
down.explanation: HIS DARK MATERIALS(i.e. “trilogy” of books by Philip Pullman). “Unconventional” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of DRAMATISE LARKISH.

down.text: Sailor in Camargue on delta, a long way from sound
down.explanation: ABSURD(i.e. “a long way from sound”). Solution is AB (i.e. a “sailor” of Able-Bodied rank) followed by SUR (i.e. “in Carmague on”, i.e. the French for “on”) and D (“delta” in the phonetic alphabet).

down.text: Drug dealer’s confession for old Irish lover
down.explanation: ISOLDE(i.e. “old Irish lover”, from the legend of Tristan and Isolde). When written as I SOLD E the solution also satisfies “drug dealer’s confession”. Nicely done.

down.text: Was boss fired again after losing it?
down.explanation: REIGNED(i.e. “was boss”). Solution is REIGNITED (i.e. “fired again”) with the IT removed (indicated by “after losing it”).

down.text: Boring advice to stop squeaking?
down.explanation: OIL WELL. Solution satisfies a “boring” and, playfully, “advice to stop squeaking”.

down.text: What Rover might do pointlessly in one’s parking place?
down.explanation: BAY AT THE MOON(i.e. a futile or “pointless” gesture). Clue plays on how you might find a lunar “rover” on THE MOON, and how “parking places” are sometimes referred to as BAYS. Nicely worked.

down.text: Scottish actor’s intention to catch LA flight
down.explanation: ALASTAIR SIM(i.e. “Scottish actor”). Solution is AIM (i.e. “intention”) wrapped around or “catching” LA and STAIRS (i.e. “flight”), like so: A(LA-STAIRS)IM. Another great clue.

down.text: Poem that’s more a novel primarily, somehow
down.explanation: TAM O’SHANTER(i.e. a “poem” by Robert Burns). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “somehow”) of THAT’S MORE A and N (i.e. “novel primarily”, i.e. the first letter of “novel”).

down.text: Very fed up as British radicals quarrel about nothing
down.explanation: BORED STIFF(i.e. “very fed up”). Solution is B (a recognised abbreviation of “British”), REDS (i.e. “radicals”) and TIFF (i.e. “quarrel”) all wrapped “about” O (i.e. “nothing”), like so: B-(O)-REDS-TIFF.

down.text: Remain calm about unsuitable acknowledgement returned
down.explanation: DON’T PANIC(i.e. “remain calm”). Solution is C (i.e. “about”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “circa”), INAPT (i.e. “unsuitable”) and NOD (i.e. “acknowledgement”) all reversed (indicated by “returned”), like so: DON-TPANI-C.

down.text: Part of maybe Mirage’s rising light over time inspiring wonderment
down.explanation: DELTA WING(i.e. “part of maybe Mirage”, a reference to a variety of French fighter jets). Solution is LED (i.e. “light”, specifically a Light Emitting Diode) reversed (indicated by “over”) and followed by T (a recognised abbreviation of “time”) and AWING (i.e. “inspiring wonderment”), like so: DEL-T-AWING. Took a brute force of my Chambers after I twigged the first few letters.

down.text: Drop liking for attack
down.explanation: TEAR INTO(i.e. “attack”). Solution is TEAR (i.e. a “drop” of water) followed by INTO (i.e. “liking”).

down.text: Make out payment finally? That is for some clothing
down.explanation: NECKTIE(i.e. “some clothing”). Solution is NECK (i.e. “make out” or smoochies) followed by T (i.e. “payment finally”, i.e. the last letter of “payment”) and IE (i.e. “that is”, i.e. “i.e.” – an abbreviation of the Latinid est).

down.text: Game that’s played could end in stalemate
down.explanation: CLUEDO(i.e. “game”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “that’s played”) of COULD and E (i.e. “end [letter] in stalemate”).

down.text: Tattoo of weaver’s remains?
down.explanation: THRUM. Solution satisfies a “tattoo” or drumming sound, and “weaver’s remains”, a variant meaning. Another new one on me.

down.text: At least three notes to get wrong
down.explanation: MISDO(i.e. “to get wrong”). When written as MIS and DO the solution also satisfies “at least three notes”, MI and DO being part of the sol-fa notation, MI in this case being plural.
